overview: It is against the law to discriminate against anyone because of their sex, religion, disability or certain other personal characteristics.
title: Discrimination - your rights

table.body:
It is against the law to discriminate against anyone because of:

- race
- sex
- sexual orientation
- disability
- religion or belief
- being a transgendered person
- being pregnant or having a child
- being married or in a civil partnership 
- age 

These are known as ‘protected characteristics’. You can be protected from discrimination because of these characteristics in the following situations:

- at work
- in education
- as a consumer
- when using public services

You are legally protected from unlawful discrimination by the [Equality Act 2010.](http://www.legislation.gov.uk/ukpga/2010/15/contents "Equality Act 2010"){:rel="external"}
table.title: Types of discrimination

table.body:
Discrimination can come in one or more of these forms:

- direct discrimination - treating someone with a protected characteristic less favourably than others in the same situation
- indirect discrimination - putting rules in place that apply to everyone, but that put someone with a protected characteristic at an unfair disadvantage
table.title: How you can be discriminated against

table.body:
The law protects you against discrimination at work, including:

- recruitment
- employment terms and conditions
- pay and benefits
- training
- promotion and transfer opportunities
- redundancy
- dismissal

Some forms of discrimination are only allowed if they're needed for the way the organisation works, eg:

- a Roman Catholic school restricting applications for a scripture teacher to Catholics only
- employing only women in a heath centre for Muslim women


##Disability

If you're disabled you have the same rights as other workers. Employers should also make 'reasonable adjustments' to help disabled employees and job-applicants with:

- application forms (eg providing forms in Braille, audio formats)
- interview arrangements (eg wheelchair access, communicator support)
- aptitude tests (eg giving extra time to complete the tests)
- making sure the workplace has the right facilities and equipment for disabled workers or someone offered a job
- terms of employment, including pay
- promotion, transfer and training opportunities
- work-related benefits like access to recreation or refreshment facilities
- dismissal or redundancy
- discipline and grievances
table.title: Discrimination at work

table.body:
If you have been unfairly discriminated against you can:

- complain directly to the person or organisation (eg by phoning or writing to them)
- use someone else to help you sort it out (called 'mediation' or 'alternative dispute resolution')
- make a claim in court

You should [contact the Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC)](contact-the-equality-and-human-rights-commission "contact the Equality and Human Rights Commission (EHRC)") - they can offer you help and advice.

##If you're discriminated against at work

Talk to your employer first to try to sort out the problem informally and read the advice on [workplace disputes](/solve-workplace-dispute/ "workplace disputes"). 

If you can't sort things out informally, talk to [Acas (the Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service),](http://www.acas.org.uk/index.aspx?articleid=1410 "Acas (the Advisory, Conciliation and Arbitration Service)"){:rel="external"}[ Citizens Advice](http://www.citizensadvice.org.uk/index/getadvice.htm "Citizens Advice"){:rel="external"} or your trade union representative. 

^You might be able to take a claim to an [Employment Tribunal](/employment-tribunals "Employment Tribunal") for discrimination.^

[EHRC]: Equality and Human Rights Commission
table.title: What you can do

table.body:

The EHRC can help you with mediation services and provide you with free advice.

table.body:
Positive action is when something is done to help someone who has a protected characteristic. Positive action is voluntary and could be taken because:

- someone is at a disadvantage due to their protected characteristic
- people with a protected characteristic have particular needs
- people with a protected characteristic are under-represented in an activity or type of work

Positive action is not illegal if it can be justified in situations such as these.
table.title: Positive action
